issues.title: energy efficiency definition
issues.author: marisolpalmero
issues.body:
I temp to disagree with this part of the definition for Energy Efficiency:
 
Energy Efficiency: : Refers to the ability to control the use of available energy in an optimized manner (e.g., in a resource conserved manner and at low cost).
 
I agree on how it is addressed in the second paragraph...
 
Energy Efficiency: :  is a ratio between the useful output and input of an energy conversion process of a network, device, or component.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I think this is now fixed in #11

comments.author: marisolpalmero
comments.body: did you commit? I still see it with the same definition?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Here is the current entry in the main:

> Energy Efficiency/Energy Efficiency Ratio (EER):
> The energy efficiency is expressed as the ratio between the useful output and input of an energy conversion process of a network, device, or component.
> 
> For instance, in relation with a networking device, it can be stated as the ratio of total throughput (e.g., of a network element capacity) to the total power consumed (bits/Joule).
> 
> This ratio (i.e., Energy Efficiency Ratio, EER) is the throughput forwarded by 1 watt (e.g., [[I-D.cprjgf-bmwg-powerbench](https://billwuqin.github.io/draft-bclp-green-terminology/draft-bclp-green-terminology.html#I-D.cprjgf-bmwg-powerbench)]).
> 
> A higher EER indicates a better energy efficiency.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
@marisolpalmero Let us know whether the change address your comment, 
I think the draft is in good shape for initial submisison.

issues.title: description needs to match the formula
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/billwuqin/draft-bclp-green-terminology/blob/f0fbc34b4964e74482a897b28d5512fba09e9917/draft-bclp-green-terminology.md?plain=1#L244C1-L251C76

There is a disconnect between the notations and the description.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
I think the formula calculation is similar to one for router and ethernet switches, I propose to make the following change:
                EER = Ti/Pw [Mbit/s/W]
Where Ti is weighted throughput between wide area network (WAN) and local area network (LAN) ports in the ingress direction, Pw is weighted power (energy consumption rate), the formula is defined in {{L.1310}}
               Ti = 0.35T_idle+0.5*T_lowpower+0.15*T_maximum
			   Pw = 0.35P_idle+0.5P_lowpower+0.15P_maximum
where (0.35,0.5,0.15)is the relative weight at different usage percentage
(P_idle, P_lowpower, P_maximum) is the power at different usage percentage
(T_idle, T_lowpower,T_maximum) is the throughput at different usage percentage

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Implement in https://github.com/billwuqin/draft-bclp-green-terminology/commit/53cbba9aa2d5607d494abed1d6e0220fb665880a

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Looks better. Thanks @billwuqin.

issues.title: Throughput vs NDR
issues.author: marisolpalmero
issues.body:
In ATIS TEER/ ETSI/ITU, it is not used the formula Ti = a*Tu1 + b*Tu2 + c*Tu3 for the traffic. It is used non-drop-rate

L.1310: title: Energy efficiency metrics and measurement methods for telecommunication equipment target: https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-L.1310-202409-P date: 2024

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I also see NDR was removed from https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/[draft-ietf-bmwg-mlrsearch-07](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-bmwg-mlrsearch-07).  It uses Throughput  as well.

comments.author: williamchern
comments.body:
Generally, there are three places where the EER and throughput are defined.
ATIS ATIS0600015.03: NDR throughput used
ITU-T L.1310: in the newest revise, NDR throughput replaced weighted throughput.
So Ti in EER should use NDR throughput.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/billwuqin/draft-bclp-green-terminology/commit/bef1e5ffc7e18fe1ef4583b722de6cef0f5ef68d, thanks WilliamChern

issues.title: Do we need to introduce capability related terminologies and definitions?
issues.author: billwuqin

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
I think we might consider to break down capability into:
1. Device Level Capability, e.g., energy saving capability, local management, network wide management, etc
2. Component Level Capability, port on or off or speed change, fan speed adjustment
3. Power interface Setting Capability: who provide power, who consume, temperature setting, voltage, ampere setting, etc

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: See definition of "Energy Efficiency Capabilities"

issues.title: Potential new term for post-IETF121 version - Energy Consumption
issues.author: luismcontreras
issues.body:
As described in my mail (01/11): "Maybe for the future versions (I will open an issue on this). We should may consider the term of Energy Consumption as basis for the Energy Efficiency. That is, identify what we are considered as included in the consumption that we are making more efficient (for instance, are we considering the cooling? Maybe not, so probably is good to define in any case what consumption is considering for obtaining the efficiency on it)."

To be discussed.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
We do currently have consumption mentioned:

> Energy Efficiency Network Management:
> Refers to the ability to control the use of available energy in an optimized manner (e.g., in a resource conserved manner and at low cost) in a network.
> 
> Energy Efficiency Metric:
> Refers to a metric that is used for the evaluation and assessment of energy consumption of a network, device, or component. One or more metrics can be defined. These metrics are also used for network performance purposes to characterize the effectiveness of an Energy Efficiency management strategy.

@luismcontreras, which change you think is worth be made? Thanks

issues.title: Adding some typical energy efficiency scenarios
issues.author: williamchern
issues.body:
As this draft has defined the widely used energy efficiency term and sample metrics, it would be necessary  to add some typical sample energy efficiency scenarios as well to show how the terms and metrics could be used in reality. The well known scenarios are tidal network and low link utilization, I listed them in the pull request for initial discussion, and sure there are more sample scenarios to be added if this is recognized as a good thing to be done. 

https://github.com/billwuqin/draft-bclp-green-terminology/pull/25

issues.title: Adding some additional terms.
issues.author: williamchern

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Leave these terms aside, I review https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-pignataro-green-enviro-sust-terminology/, a set of terms are relevant as follows:
1.Energy, power, and their measurement
2.Energy efficiency (EE)
3.Energy proportionality 
4.Energy savings / conservation (ES) 
I think the first 2 terms have already been covered, for Energy proportionality, try to understand how it is different from energy efficiency, PUE, can we use it to measure the ratio between energy consmption by linecard and energy consumption of the whole network device?
For Energy saving or Energy Conservation, I think it is the effect of implementing the enegy efficiency strategy.
@boucadair

comments.author: billwuqin
williamchern
comments.body:
I agree, Energy saving features relies on the context, and  EEE is certain technology, I thought that well-known technology for energy saving is good to be clarified here. 
Anyway, the term of "site energy efficiency" though coming from wireless related  ETSI standard, but it shares the same context for all network devices like optical and datacom devices, etc.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body: site energy efficiency is 3GPP specific term.

issues.title: Energy Management vs Energy Efficiency Network Management
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
One of comments raised by Benoit on the list make me rethink the relationship between Energy management and Energy Efficiency network management , see two defintions quoted in the draft:
"
**Energy Management**:
Is a set of functions for measuring, modeling, planning, and optimizing networks to ensure that the network and network-attached devices use energy efficiently and appropriately for the nature of the application and the cost constraints of the organization ([RFC7326]).

**Energy Efficiency Network Management**:
: Refers to the ability to manage (including control) the use of
  available energy in an optimized manner (e.g.,in a resource conserved manner and at low cost) in a network.
"
How enegy efficiency network management is different from Energy management? 
I think first, Energy management defintion doesn't consider inventory and discovery function, second, unlike energy management, energy effficiency management is to set a clear goal for energy efficiency and use energy efficiency metric to assess energy consumption of a network so that the management system can manage the use of avaialbe energy in an optmized manner in the network.

Two options we have:
1. Consolidate Energy efficiency network management definition with Energy Management defintion
2. If we choose to keep both, we need to make sure Energy Efficiency network management is built on  top of Energy Management defintion

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
One solution proposed by China Unicom is:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/green/uSl1paEO6mgMT73jBwX9xD2wsy4/

comments.body: Relevant to #30
